entry.name: Comparison of ribosomes between control and dyskerin-depleted human cells
entry.description: Dyskerin is a pseudouridine synthase involved in fundamental cellular processes (including rRNA and snRNA modification and telomere stabilization), whose function is altered in X-linked dyskeratosis congenita and cancer. Dyskerin role in ribosome processing was suggested to underlie the alterations in mRNA translation described in cells lacking dyskerin function. We compared the protein contents of 5 replicates of ribosomal preparations from control or dyskerin-depleted human cells.

additional_fields.field: Ribosomes were extracted from human MCF7 cells, in which dyskerin expression was inhibited (n=5) or not (n=5). Proteins from enriched ribosomes were solubilized in Laemmli buffer before stacking of proteins in the top of a 4-12% NuPAGE gel (Life Techologies) and R-250 Coomassie blue staining. The gel bands were manually excised and proteins in-gel digested using trypsin. Peptides from each sample were analysed in duplicates by nanoLC-MS/MS using an Ultimate 3000 LC (Dionex) coupled to a LTQ-Orbitrap Velos pro (ThermoFisher). Label-free quantification was performed using the MaxQuant software.

RAW files were processed using MaxQuant version 1.4.1.2. Spectra were searched against the Uniprot database (Homo sapiens taxonomy, August 2013 version) and the frequently observed contaminants database embedded in MaxQuant. Trypsin was chosen as the enzyme and 2 missed cleavages were allowed. Precursor mass error tolerances were set respectively at 20 ppm and 4.5 ppm for first and main searches. Fragment mass error tolerance was set to 0.5 Da. Peptide modifications allowed during the search were: carbamidomethylation (C, fixed), acetyl (Protein N-ter, variable) and oxidation (M, variable). Minimum peptide length was set to 7 amino acids. Minimum number of peptides, razor + unique peptides and unique peptides were all set to 1. Maximum false discovery rates - calculated by employing a reverse database strategy - were set to 0.01.
translation ; ribosomes ; dyskerin ; nanoLC-MS/MS ; label-free quantification

Penzo M, Rocchi L, Brugiere S, Carnicelli D, Onofrillo C, Couté Y, Brigotti M, Montanaro L. Human ribosomes from cells with reduced dyskerin levels are intrinsically altered in translation. FASEB J. 2015 May 1. pii: fj.15-270991
Laboratoire d'Etude de la Dynamique des ProtÃ©omes
